title: Psalms Chapter 141 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 141 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 141 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 141.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalm 141 according to the chapter text?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalm 141 begins with 'A Psalm of David,' indicating David as the author (Psalms 141:1).

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask the LORD to do when he cries unto Him?
questions.correctAnswer: Make haste
questions.explanation: The psalmist prays, 'LORD, I cry unto thee: make haste unto me' (Psalms 141:1).

questions.question: In Psalms 141:2, how does the psalmist describe his prayer?
options: As incense and the evening sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: As incense and the evening sacrifice
questions.explanation: The prayer is described as 'incense' and 'the lifting up of my hands as the evening sacrifice' (Psalms 141:2).

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask the LORD to set before his mouth?
questions.correctAnswer: A watch
questions.explanation: He asks, 'Set a watch, O LORD, before my mouth' (Psalms 141:3).

questions.question: According to Psalms 141:4, what does the psalmist ask God not to incline his heart toward?
questions.correctAnswer: Evil things
questions.explanation: He prays, 'Incline not my heart to any evil thing' (Psalms 141:4).

questions.question: What does the psalmist say about being smitten by the righteous in Psalms 141:5?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be a kindness
questions.explanation: He states, 'Let the righteous smite me; it shall be a kindness' (Psalms 141:5).

questions.question: What is described as 'an excellent oil, which shall not break my head'?
questions.correctAnswer: The reproof from the righteous
questions.explanation: The psalmist says, 'let him reprove me; it shall be an excellent oil, which shall not break my head' (Psalms 141:5).

questions.question: What will happen when the judges are overthrown in stony places, according to Psalms 141:6?
options: They shall hear the psalmist's words
questions.correctAnswer: They shall hear the psalmist's words
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'When their judges are overthrown... they shall hear my words' (Psalms 141:6).

questions.question: What simile is used in Psalms 141:7 to describe the scattering of bones?
options: As when one cutteth and cleaveth wood upon the earth
questions.correctAnswer: As when one cutteth and cleaveth wood upon the earth
questions.explanation: The bones are scattered 'as when one cutteth and cleaveth wood upon the earth' (Psalms 141:7).

questions.question: According to Psalms 141:8, where are the psalmist's eyes directed?
questions.correctAnswer: To the LORD God
questions.explanation: He says, 'But mine eyes are unto thee, O GOD the Lord' (Psalms 141:8).

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God not to leave his soul as, according to Psalms 141:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Destitute
questions.explanation: The psalmist pleads, 'leave not my soul destitute' (Psalms 141:8).

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist asks to be kept from snares and gins of workers of iniquity.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: He prays, 'Keep me from the snares which they have laid for me, and the gins of the workers of iniquity' (Psalms 141:9).

questions.question: True or False: Psalm 141 says that the wicked will succeed in trapping the psalmist.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks, 'Let the wicked fall into their own nets, whilst that I withal escape' (Psalms 141:10).

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist compares his prayer to an evening sacrifice.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: He says, 'and the lifting up of my hands as the evening sacrifice' (Psalms 141:2).

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 141:3: 'Set a ______, O LORD, before my mouth; keep the door of my lips.'
questions.correctAnswer: watch
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Set a watch, O LORD, before my mouth' (Psalms 141:3).

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 141 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 141 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with persistent temptation to sin. Based on Psalms 141, what biblical truth would you share about resisting evil desires?
options: Ask God to set a watch before your mouth and guard your lips
Ignore the temptation and it will go away
Confess your sins only to people, not to God
Avoid prayer because it weakens resolve
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to set a watch before your mouth and guard your lips
questions.explanation: Psalms 141:3 teaches us to ask God to guard our speech and keep us from speaking evil, which is vital in resisting temptation. Verses 4 and 9 also emphasize turning away from evil and snares of workers of iniquity.

questions.question: How does Psalms 141:2 illustrate the importance of prayer and personal devotion in spiritual discipline?
options: Prayer is compared to incense and lifting hands as an evening sacrifice
Prayer is only necessary on feast days
Prayer is only for confessing sins
Prayer should be silent and never lifted with hands
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is compared to incense and lifting hands as an evening sacrifice
questions.explanation: Verse 2 compares prayer to incense and lifting hands to the evening sacrifice, showing prayer as a continual, pleasing act of devotion and worship before God.

questions.question: In the context of dealing with correction and reproving, what attitude toward discipline does Psalms 141:5 teach us?
options: Receiving correction is a kindness and excellent oil for the head
Ignore correction to keep your pride
Only friends can correct you, not the righteous
Avoid all criticism to maintain peace
questions.correctAnswer: Receiving correction is a kindness and excellent oil for the head
questions.explanation: Verse 5 explains that being corrected by the righteous is a kindness and like excellent oil, which benefits rather than harms us, teaching humility and openness to godly discipline.

questions.question: What practical wisdom for perseverance through trials can be drawn from Psalms 141:8?
options: Keep your eyes on God and trust Him not to leave your soul destitute
Rely on your own strength and ignore God
Avoid looking to God during hard times
questions.correctAnswer: Keep your eyes on God and trust Him not to leave your soul destitute
questions.explanation: Verse 8 encourages believers to fix their eyes on God and trust Him, especially when enduring trials, promising that He will not abandon the soul.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to join others in sinful practices for social gain. According to Psalms 141:4, what guidance would you give?
options: Do not incline your heart to evil or take part in wicked works with those who practice iniquity
Join them to avoid being isolated
Ignore your heart's inclinations and follow the crowd
Accept their gifts and favors to gain favor
questions.correctAnswer: Do not incline your heart to evil or take part in wicked works with those who practice iniquity
questions.explanation: Verse 4 warns against inclining the heart toward evil or participating in wicked deeds with workers of iniquity, emphasizing personal holiness and separation from sin.

questions.question: How does Psalms 141:10 teach us about the outcome for the wicked and the believer's hope?
options: The wicked will fall into their own nets while the believer escapes
Both the wicked and believer suffer equally
The wicked prosper and the believer suffers
The believer should trap the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked will fall into their own nets while the believer escapes
questions.explanation: Verse 10 expresses confidence that the wicked will be caught by their own schemes, while the believer will be preserved and escape harm.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 141 encourages believers to trust in their own wisdom over God's guidance in times of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The Psalm emphasizes trusting God (verse 8) and seeking His help rather than relying on human wisdom in trials (verses 1, 3, 9).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 141, a believer should welcome correction from righteous people as beneficial for spiritual growth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 5 teaches that correction from the righteous is a kindness and like excellent oil, promoting spiritual growth and humility.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 141:1 says, 'LORD, I cry unto thee: make haste unto me; give ear unto my ________, when I cry unto thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: voice
questions.explanation: Verse 1 specifically asks God to give ear to the Psalmist's voice when he cries out, emphasizing the urgency and personal nature of prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 141:9 instruct believers to handle the traps set by workers of iniquity?
options: Ask God to keep you from their snares and traps
Ignore the traps and continue as usual
Set traps for them in return
Avoid prayer and focus on worldly wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to keep you from their snares and traps
questions.explanation: Verse 9 expresses a plea for God's protection from the snares and traps laid by evildoers, highlighting dependence on divine deliverance.

questions.question: What does Psalms 141:6 suggest about the impact of a godly person's words even in difficult circumstances?
options: Their words remain sweet and influential even when judges are overthrown
Their words are ignored during trials
Their words are only for themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Their words remain sweet and influential even when judges are overthrown
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that even when judges fall in difficult places, the godly person's words are still heard and are sweet, showing the enduring power of righteous speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 141:7 poetically describe the state of the righteous during times of death or destruction?
options: Their bones are scattered at the grave’s mouth like wood being cut upon the earth
They are hidden like precious stones
They are carried away by the wind
questions.correctAnswer: Their bones are scattered at the grave’s mouth like wood being cut upon the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 7 uses vivid imagery comparing bones scattered at the grave to wood being cut and split, illustrating mortality and the harsh reality of death.

questions.question: What does Psalms 141:3 imply about the importance of controlling what we say in daily life?
options: God’s watch over our speech helps prevent sin from our lips
Speech is unimportant and can be ignored
Only written words matter, not spoken ones
Silence is always better than speaking
questions.correctAnswer: God’s watch over our speech helps prevent sin from our lips
questions.explanation: Verse 3 requests God to set a watch before the mouth and guard the lips, emphasizing the spiritual discipline of controlling speech to avoid sin.

questions.question: How does Psalms 141 suggest believers should respond to the calamities of others, particularly those who correct them?
options: Pray for them even in their calamities
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for them even in their calamities
questions.explanation: Verse 5 indicates that even when corrected by the righteous, the Psalmist will pray for them in their calamities, showing love and intercession.

questions.question: What practical lesson about trust does Psalms 141:8 offer for Christian living?
options: Keep your eyes on God and place trust in Him to not abandon your soul
Trust your own understanding above all
Avoid looking to God in difficult times
Place trust in worldly leaders instead
questions.correctAnswer: Keep your eyes on God and place trust in Him to not abandon your soul
questions.explanation: Verse 8 teaches believers to maintain focus on God and trust Him fully, especially in challenging times, ensuring the soul is not left destitute.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 141 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 141.

questions.question: In Psalms 141:2, the psalmist compares his prayer to what form of worship in the temple?
questions.correctAnswer: Incense and evening sacrifice
questions.explanation: Psalms 141:2 states, 'Let my prayer be set forth before thee as incense; and the lifting up of my hands as the evening sacrifice,' directly comparing prayer to these temple rituals symbolizing purity and acceptance.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Psalms 141:3 when the psalmist asks God to 'set a watch before my mouth; keep the door of my lips'?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The psalmist uses a metaphor by personifying the mouth and lips as a guarded door that needs a watchman, emphasizing self-control over speech (Psalms 141:3).

questions.question: According to Psalms 141:4, what does the psalmist pray to be kept from inclining his heart toward?
questions.correctAnswer: Any evil thing
questions.explanation: Psalms 141:4 states, 'Incline not my heart to any evil thing, to practise wicked works with men that work iniquity,' indicating the psalmist’s plea to avoid evil inclinations.

questions.question: In Psalms 141:5, the psalmist compares reproof from the righteous to what substance that does not break the head?
questions.correctAnswer: Excellent oil
questions.explanation: The verse uses 'excellent oil' as a metaphor for reproof from the righteous, highlighting its healing and soothing quality, which 'shall not break my head' (Psalms 141:5).

questions.question: What does Psalms 141:6 say will happen to the judges when they are overthrown in stony places?
options: They shall hear the psalmist's words
questions.correctAnswer: They shall hear the psalmist's words
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'When their judges are overthrown in stony places, they shall hear my words; for they are sweet,' indicating that even the fallen judges will acknowledge the psalmist's words (Psalms 141:6).

questions.question: How does the imagery in Psalms 141:7, 'Our bones are scattered at the grave's mouth, as when one cutteth and cleaveth wood upon the earth,' contribute to the psalm's overall tone?
options: It evokes a tone of despair and vulnerability
questions.correctAnswer: It evokes a tone of despair and vulnerability
questions.explanation: The imagery of bones scattered like wood being chopped depicts fragility and mortality, contributing to a tone of lament and vulnerability (Psalms 141:7).

questions.question: In Psalms 141:8, to whom does the psalmist look with unwavering trust?
questions.correctAnswer: God the Lord
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares, 'But mine eyes are unto thee, O GOD the Lord: in thee is my trust; leave not my soul destitute' (Psalms 141:8), showing reliance on divine help.

questions.question: What is the historical-cultural significance of the psalmist asking God to keep him from 'the snares which they have laid for me' in Psalms 141:9?
options: It reflects the common ancient Near Eastern practice of ambush and traps in warfare
It references a ritual cleansing practice
It describes a temple purification rite
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the common ancient Near Eastern practice of ambush and traps in warfare
questions.explanation: The plea to be kept from snares and gins reflects the dangers of ambushes and traps common in ancient Near Eastern warfare and conflict contexts (Psalms 141:9).

questions.question: What is the thematic significance of the psalmist’s request in Psalms 141:10, 'Let the wicked fall into their own nets, whilst that I withal escape'?
options: It illustrates the theme of divine justice and protection
It reflects a call for revenge
It expresses despair over personal failure
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the theme of divine justice and protection
questions.explanation: The verse expresses trust in God’s justice where the wicked face consequences, while the psalmist is preserved, emphasizing divine protection (Psalms 141:10).

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 141:1, the psalmist calls upon God to delay in answering his cry.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalmist actually asks God to 'make haste unto me' and 'give ear unto my voice' (Psalms 141:1), indicating urgency rather than delay.

questions.question: Which New Testament concept is foreshadowed by the psalmist’s request in Psalms 141:3 to 'keep the door of my lips'?
options: Guarding the tongue as advised in James 3:2-12
questions.correctAnswer: Guarding the tongue as advised in James 3:2-12
questions.explanation: The metaphor of guarding speech in Psalms 141:3 parallels New Testament teachings on controlling the tongue in James 3:2-12, emphasizing the power and need for restraint in speech.

questions.question: How does the psalmist’s description of prayer as 'incense' in Psalms 141:2 connect with the intertextual theme of worship in Exodus?
options: It recalls the use of incense on the altar of incense in the tabernacle described in Exodus 30
It refers to the incense used in the golden calf worship
It symbolizes rejection of temple worship
It foreshadows the destruction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It recalls the use of incense on the altar of incense in the tabernacle described in Exodus 30
questions.explanation: The prayer likened to incense connects with Exodus 30’s description of incense offerings in the tabernacle, symbolizing prayers rising to God as a fragrant offering (Psalms 141:2).

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist’s trust in God to not leave his soul destitute in the context of ancient Near Eastern beliefs, as seen in Psalms 141:8?
options: It contrasts the psalmist’s faith with common ancient fears of abandonment by gods
It affirms the psalmist’s fear of death
It expresses uncertainty about the afterlife
It indicates reliance on human kings
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts the psalmist’s faith with common ancient fears of abandonment by gods
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, gods were often seen as capricious; the psalmist’s confident trust that God will not abandon him (Psalms 141:8) highlights a distinct faith in a reliable deity.

questions.question: Which Hebrew word concept in Psalms 141:5, translated as 'kindness,' reflects the theological idea of loving correction by the righteous?
questions.correctAnswer: Chesed (חֶסֶד)
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'chesed' often translated as kindness or lovingkindness, is implied in the 'kindness' of the righteous reproof in Psalms 141:5, reflecting covenantal love expressed through correction.

questions.question: True or False: The psalmist in Psalms 141 describes his prayer as both a request for protection and an expression of hope in God’s justice.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Throughout Psalms 141, the psalmist asks God for protection ('keep the door of my lips,' 'keep me from snares') and expresses hope that the wicked will fall into their own nets (Psalms 141:3, 9, 10).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 141 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 141 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 141:2, the Psalmist compares prayer to what offering?
questions.correctAnswer: Incense
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:2 explicitly states that prayer is set forth before God as incense, symbolizing the pleasing aroma and acceptability of prayer. Similarly, Revelation 8:3-4 depicts prayers of the saints as incense before God, and Exodus 30:7-8 commands burning incense as a continual offering.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask God to set before his mouth in Psalms 141:3?
questions.correctAnswer: A watch
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:3 requests God to set a watch before the mouth, which means guarding speech from sin. Proverbs 21:23 underscores the wisdom of guarding one’s tongue, James 3:2-10 teaches about taming the tongue, and Ephesians 4:29 exhorts wholesome speech.

questions.question: According to Psalms 141:4, what does the Psalmist request God to prevent his heart from inclining towards?
questions.correctAnswer: Any evil thing
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:4 asks God not to incline the heart to any evil thing or wicked works. This aligns with Jeremiah 17:9 about the deceitfulness of the heart, Romans 7:18 about the sin in human nature, and James 1:14-15 regarding temptation leading to sin.

questions.question: In Psalms 141:5, what does the Psalmist say about being reproved by the righteous?
options: It shall be kindness and excellent oil that shall not break his head
It shall be a burden and sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be kindness and excellent oil that shall not break his head
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:5 states that reproof from the righteous is a kindness, like excellent oil that does not break the head, symbolizing healing and blessing. Proverbs 27:6 affirms that wounds from a friend are trustworthy, Hebrews 12:6 explains God’s discipline as loving, and 2 Timothy 3:16 highlights instruction for correction.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist declare about his prayer in the calamities of the righteous in Psalms 141:5?
options: His prayer shall also be in their calamities
questions.correctAnswer: His prayer shall also be in their calamities
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:5 shows the Psalmist’s solidarity with the righteous by praying even during their calamities, indicating intercessory prayer. This reflects Romans 12:15 about rejoicing and mourning with others, James 5:16 on praying for one another, and 1 Timothy 2:1’s call for intercession.

questions.question: According to Psalms 141:6, what will happen when judges are overthrown in stony places?
options: They shall hear the Psalmist’s words because they are sweet
They shall be silent and fearful
questions.correctAnswer: They shall hear the Psalmist’s words because they are sweet
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:6 expresses that even when judges fall, they will hear the Psalmist’s sweet words, symbolizing God’s justice and the power of righteous speech. This aligns with Proverbs 16:12 on the fall of rulers, Ecclesiastes 12:14 on words being judged, and Matthew 12:36 about accountability for words.

questions.question: What imagery does Psalms 141:7 use to describe the scattering of bones at the grave's mouth?
options: Like one cutting and cleaving wood upon the earth
Like leaves scattered by the wind
Like dust blown in the desert
Like stones rolling down a hill
questions.correctAnswer: Like one cutting and cleaving wood upon the earth
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:7 uses the vivid image of scattered bones as if cut and cleaved wood on the earth, emphasizing mortality and destruction. This echoes Job 14:12 about returning to dust, Ezekiel 37:7’s valley of dry bones, and Ecclesiastes 3:20 on death’s universality.

questions.question: To whom does the Psalmist lift his eyes and trust according to Psalms 141:8?
questions.correctAnswer: O God the Lord
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:8 declares the Psalmist’s trust is in God the Lord, seeking Him to not leave his soul destitute. This reflects Proverbs 3:5-6 on trusting God, Psalm 121:1-2 on lifting eyes to the hills, and Hebrews 13:5 about God’s presence.

questions.question: In Psalms 141:9, from what does the Psalmist ask God to keep him?
options: Snares and gins of workers of iniquity
questions.correctAnswer: Snares and gins of workers of iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:9 requests protection from traps and snares laid by evildoers, highlighting the reality of spiritual and moral dangers. This aligns with Proverbs 22:5 on evil men’s snares, Matthew 26:41 on watchfulness against temptation, and 2 Timothy 2:26 on escaping the devil’s snare.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist desire to happen to the wicked in Psalms 141:10?
options: Let them fall into their own nets while he escapes
Let them be forgiven and restored
questions.correctAnswer: Let them fall into their own nets while he escapes
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:10 expresses a plea for divine justice where the wicked fall into their own traps but the Psalmist escapes. This theme of God’s justice is seen in Proverbs 1:10-19 on the fate of evildoers, Psalm 37:12-15 about the wicked’s traps, and Romans 12:19 affirming vengeance belongs to God.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the Psalmist’s attitude toward reproof in Psalms 141:5?
options: He welcomes it as kindness and healing
questions.correctAnswer: He welcomes it as kindness and healing
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:5 reveals the Psalmist’s positive reception of correction from the righteous, viewing it as kindness and healing oil. Proverbs 12:1 states that loving correction is wise, Hebrews 12:11 explains discipline produces righteousness, and Psalm 94:12 blesses those taught by God.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist mean by 'keep the door of my lips' in Psalms 141:3?
options: Let my words be loud and clear
questions.correctAnswer: Guard my speech from sin
questions.explanation: In Psalm 141:3, 'keep the door of my lips' means guarding one’s speech to prevent sin. This concept is echoed in Proverbs 10:19 about avoiding many words, James 1:26 on bridling the tongue, and Ephesians 4:29 encouraging edifying speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 141:1 express the Psalmist's urgency in prayer?
options: By crying unto the LORD and asking Him to make haste
By shouting loudly in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By crying unto the LORD and asking Him to make haste
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:1 shows the Psalmist crying to the LORD and asking for haste in hearing, demonstrating urgent dependence on God. Similar urgency is seen in Psalm 40:13, Luke 18:7 on persistent prayer, and Isaiah 30:19 where God hears in due time.

questions.question: What does the 'evening sacrifice' in Psalms 141:2 symbolize in the context of prayer?
options: A continual offering of worship and prayer
A ritual performed by priests alone
questions.correctAnswer: A continual offering of worship and prayer
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:2 likens prayer to the evening sacrifice, symbolizing ongoing worship and devotion. Exodus 29:38-42 describes daily sacrifices, Zechariah 14:7 prophesies continual offerings, and Hebrews 13:15 urges continual praise through Jesus.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'leave not my soul destitute' in Psalms 141:8 indicate about the Psalmist’s understanding of God’s care?
options: A plea for God’s sustaining presence and provision
A desire to be left alone
questions.correctAnswer: A plea for God’s sustaining presence and provision
questions.explanation: Psalm 141:8 expresses a plea for God not to abandon the soul, highlighting dependence on God’s sustaining care. This is consistent with Psalm 23:4’s comfort in God’s presence, Isaiah 41:10’s assurance of help, and John 6:35 where Jesus is the bread of life.
